subsection.name: 1.1. Does Apache Trinidad depend on any particular implementation of JSF?
subsection.p: No. If there is an Oracle-specific implementation of JSF, Apache Trinidad will be optimized to run best on that implementation, but we believe it is important that Apache Trinidad run on any implementation of the JSF 1.1 specification (or later). Apache Trinidad can be used with either the Sun Reference Implementation 1.1_01 or MyFaces 1.0.8 (or later).

subsection.name: 1.2. What runtime or design time tools can I use to run the demo WAR?
subsection.p: Please see the platform section on the installation page for information on how to deploy to JDeveloper, standalone OC4J, and Tomcat.
Although Apache Trinidad is "vanilla" JSF we have not been able to run with Java Studio Creator Build 04.06.2. We are working with Sun to resolve the issues in Java Studio Creator.

We have done some limited testing on IBM WebSphere Studio Application Developer 5.1.2. We have been able to run using .jsp, but not .jspx. If you are running the demo WAR please make sure the file names in faces-config.xml reflect any updated file names.

subsection.name: 2.1. Can I use standard Faces tags with Apache Trinidad?
subsection.p: Yes; all standard Faces tags can be used with Apache Trinidad. You can even use <h:form> instead of <af:form> without losing any Apache Trinidad functionality.

subsection.name: 2.2. Why would I use Apache Trinidad instead of standard Faces?
subsection.p: Good question. Here's a list of some of the advantages

p.i: The items in italics are either not yet available or only partially implemented

ol.li: Provide more efficient implementations of client-side state saving (reduced per-component size)
Rich set of components, validators, and converters

Apache Trinidad tags often offer more features than the standard tags; for example, all input components offer built-in label and message display support ( For more information on the differences between the Apache Trinidad tags and the standard Faces tags, please see the following document).
Client-side converters/validators - JavaScript enabled converters and validators that attempt to catch and display errors on the client
Apache Trinidad tags can be used inside of the <af:forEach> tag (it is, unfortunately, not possible to support standard tags inside <af:forEach>).

li.i: Accessibility - support similar to ADF UIX Accessibility

Bidirectional language support - Apache Trinidad components automatically render themselves appropriately for bidirectional languages. Users can also use the "start" and "end" constants described in ADF UIX Bidirectional Language Support

ol.li: Partial Page Rendering (PPR) - support similar to ADF UIX PPR overview

li.i: Skinning - support similar to ADF UIX Look and Feel

ol.li: ADF integration - including support for JSR227 (Data binding)

subsection.name: 2.3. What is the relationship between Apache Trinidad and ADF UIX?
subsection.p: Apache Trinidad is a significant evolution of the ADF UIX code. The proprietary API (UINode, RenderingContext, etc.) of ADF UIX has been replaced with the standard JSF API, and we've added many features to our components that take advantage of the JSF architecture. In making this change, we've also overhauled nearly all our component names and attribute names to fit in closely with JSF naming conventions. ADF UIX and Apache Trinidad can be installed in a single web application without conflicts.

subsection.name: 3.1. When I run a JSP, I see 'javax.servlet.jsp.JspException: Cannot find FacesContext'
subsection.p: You cannot directly point to a JSF JSP file; you either need to add "/faces" after the servlet context path, or change the suffix (in the URL only) to ".faces".

subsection.name: 3.2. I'm getting a java.lang.ClassCastException in UIXComponentTag.setProperties()
subsection.p: JSF requires the <f:view> JSP tag around all JSF JSP tags; this obscure error is the result of failing to include <f:view>.

subsection.name: 3.3. I'm having a problem seeing dialog windows
subsection.p: You may have trouble seeing dialogs if you have popup blockers installed.

subsection.name: 3.4. I'm seeing the error '"af:commandButton" must have value or image attributes.'
subsection.p: You are using JSF 1.0 (this is a bug in the JSF 1.0 RI) and Apache Trinidad requires JSF 1.1.

subsection.name: 3.5. I'm seeing the error 'method assert(boolean) not found in class [XXX]'
subsection.p: You need to enable J2SE 1.4 Assertions. In jdev this can be done in project properties (Select Tools -> Project Properties -> Profiles -> Development -> Compiler -> Enable J2SE 1.4 Assertions.)

subsection.name: 3.6. My page looks really bad, as if it was totally unstyled
subsection.p: You may have not have configured your Resources Servlet in your web.xml. Please refer to installation instructions to configure the ResourceServlet.

subsection.name: 3.6. My input field is just showing as plain text when not in read-only mode.
subsection.p: You may be missing the "setXyz()" function matching the "getXyz()" function that is controlling your field's value, or you might have mispelled its name. This makes that property read-only. When Apache Trinidad detects that an input field is using a read-only model property, it automatically switches the field to read-only mode, which is why it looks like plain text. For what it's worth, if you tried the same model property with <h:inputText>, it'd look fine when you first render the page, but JSF would throw an exception when you posted back to the server and it couldn't write the new value into the model.

subsection.name: 4.1. What is the status of the Apache Trinidad Podling?'
subsection.p: Apache Trinidad is an effort undergoing incubation at The Apache Software Foundation (ASF), sponsored by the Apache MyFaces PMC. Incubation is required of all newly accepted projects until a further review indicates that the infrastructure, communications, and decision making process have stabilized in a manner consistent with other successful ASF projects. While incubation status is not necessarily a reflection of the completeness or stability of the code, it does indicate that the project has yet to be fully endorsed by the ASF.
